reg:regulation.reg:title:
Environmental Protection and
Management Regulation
reg:regulation.reg:amsincluded: [includes amendments up to B.C. Reg. 41/2016, February 29, 2016]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Oil and Gas Activities Act;
deep groundwater has the same meaning as in section 51 of the Water Sustainability Regulation;

fish habitat means wildlife habitat in or about a fish stream, including but not limited to spawning grounds and nursery, rearing, food supply and migration areas, on which fish depend directly or indirectly to survive and carry out their life processes;
fish stream means a stream that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is frequented by any of the following species of fish:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: anadromous salmonids;

rainbow trout, cutthroat trout, brown trout, bull trout, Dolly Varden char, lake trout, brook trout, kokanee, largemouth bass, smallmouth bass, mountain whitefish, lake whitefish, arctic grayling, burbot, white sturgeon, black crappie, yellow perch, walleye or northern pike;
a species identified as a species at risk by an order under section 29 (a);
a species identified as regionally important wildlife by an order under section 29 (b), or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has a slope gradient of less than 20%, unless the watercourse

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: does not contain any of the species of fish referred to in paragraph (a),
is located upstream of a natural barrier to fish passage and all reaches upstream of the barrier are simultaneously dry at any time during the year, or
is located upstream of a natural barrier to fish passage and no perennial fish habitat exists upstream of the barrier;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: groundwater capture zone means an area of land that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contributes groundwater to a water supply well that is part of a water supply system under the Drinking Water Protection Act, and
is identified as a groundwater capture zone

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the Integrated Land and Resource Registry, maintained under section 7.2 of the Land Act, or
in the Land and Resource Data Warehouse maintained by the minister responsible for the Land Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: identified groundwater recharge area means a groundwater recharge area identified in an order under section 34 (b);

natural range barrier means a river, rock face or any other naturally occurring feature that stops or significantly impedes livestock movement to and from an adjacent area that is identified as a natural range barrier

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the Integrated Land and Resource Registry, maintained under section 7.2 of the Land Act, or
in the Land and Resource Data Warehouse maintained by the minister responsible for the Land Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: oil and gas activity, in sections 9 and 20, does not include the diversion and use of water from a water source well unless the activity is the diversion and use of deep groundwater under the Water Sustainability Act;
oil and gas road has the same meaning as in the Oil and Gas Road Regulation;
pipeline corridor means the area identified in a permit within which a pipeline may be constructed;
riparian management area means an area that consists of a riparian management zone and a riparian reserve zone;
road right of way has the same meaning as in the Oil and Gas Road Regulation;

seismic line means the area within which the trees are removed or the vegetation is modified for the purposes of carrying out geophysical exploration, and includes any associated access trails and equipment staging areas;
water supply wellhas the same meaning as in section 1 (1) of the Groundwater Protection Regulation, but does not include a water source well;
waterworks means a water supply intake, water storage reservoir, whether natural or manmade, water diversion structure or water supply system, if the intake, reservoir, structure or system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: licensed or the subject of an approval for short-term use under the Water Sustainability Act, or
a domestic water system, as defined in the Drinking Water Protection Act, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is identified

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the Integrated Land and Resource Registry, maintained under section 7.2 of the Land Act, or
in the Land and Resource Data Warehouse maintained by the minister responsible for the Land Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: wildlife tree means a tree or group of trees that is identified in the Resource Silviculture Updates and Land Status Tracking System maintained by the minister responsible for the Forest Act as a wildlife tree or as being in a wildlife tree retention area;
wildlife tree retention area has the same meaning as in section 1 (1) of the Forest Planning and Practices Regulation, B.C. Reg. 14/2004.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the Act and this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: aquifer means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a geological formation,
a group of geological formations, or
a part of one or more geological formations that contains water with up to 4 000 milligrams per litre of total dissolved solids and is capable of storing, transmitting and yielding that water;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: cultural heritage resource means an object, a site or the location of a traditional societal practice that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for non-treaty areas,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is of historical, cultural or archaeological significance to an aboriginal people,
is the focus of a traditional use by an aboriginal people that is of continuing importance to that people, and
is not regulated under the Heritage Conservation Act, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for treaty areas

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is subject to a treaty right, and
is not regulated under the Heritage Conservation Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: designated watershed means a designated watershed established in an order under section 35;
fisheries sensitive watershed means a fisheries sensitive watershed established in an order under section 27;
invasive plant means a species of plant identified in an order under section 33;

stream means a watercourse, including a watercourse that is obscured by overhanging or bridging vegetation or soil mats, that contains water on a perennial or seasonal basis, is scoured by water or contains observable deposits of mineral alluvium, and that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has a continuous channel bed that is 100 m or more in length, or
flows directly into

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a fish stream or a fish-bearing lake or wetland, or
a waterworks;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: temperature sensitive stream means a temperature sensitive stream identified in an order under section 28;
ungulate winter range means an ungulate winter range established in an order under section 31;
wildlife means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vertebrates that are mammals, birds, fish, reptiles or amphibians,
invertebrates,
plants, and
lichens

bcl:definition.bcl:text: and includes all stages of development of the vertebrates, invertebrates, plants or lichens;

wildlife habitat means the physical and biological components and characteristics of the environment, including air, soil, water, food and cover, on which wildlife depend directly or indirectly to survive and carry out their life processes;
wildlife habitat area means a wildlife habitat area established in an order under section 30;
wildlife habitat feature means a wildlife habitat feature identified in an order under section 26.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This regulation applies only to Crown land and does not apply to subsurface oil and gas activities associated with an operating area.
In this regulation, a reference to distance is a reference to the slope distance.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, wellsite does not include the site of a water source well unless the water source well is being used under the Water Sustainability Act for the diversion of deep groundwater.

The following objectives with respect to water quality, quantity and timing of flow are prescribed for the purposes of the definition of "government's environmental objectives" in section 1 (2) of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that wellsites, facility areas, road right of way and pipeline corridors not be located within

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: 100 m of where water is diverted by a waterworks or stored in a water storage reservoir, or
100 m of where water is diverted by a water supply well or the groundwater capture zone for the water supply well, whichever is greater,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any adverse effects on the waterworks, water supply well, water storage reservoir or groundwater capture zone can be effectively mitigated, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that operating areas not be located

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: within an identified groundwater recharge area,
within a designated watershed, or
on top of an identified aquifer

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: unless the operating area will not have a material adverse effect on the quality and quantity of water and the natural timing of water flow.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following objectives with respect to riparian values are prescribed for the purposes of the definition of "government's environmental objectives" in section 1 (2) of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that operating areas not be located within any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a stream, except to facilitate the crossing of the stream;
a lake, except to facilitate

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the crossing of the lake, or
geophysical exploration on lakes that are frozen to the bottom;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a wetland with a riparian class of W2, except to facilitate the crossing of the wetland;
an enclosed upland within a wetland, unless

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the wetland has a riparian class of W1 or W3,
the enclosed upland is greater than 5 ha, and
it is not practicable to locate the operating area elsewhere;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a riparian reserve zone except to facilitate a crossing of the applicable stream, wetland or lake;
except to facilitate a crossing, a riparian management zone, unless an operating area will not have a material adverse effect on the ability of the riparian management zone to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: conserve the fish habitat, wildlife habitat, biodiversity and the water values of the riparian management zone, and
protect the riparian reserve zone, if any, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that sufficient streamside trees and understory vegetation be retained to prevent the temperature of a temperature sensitive stream from increasing or decreasing to an extent that would have a material adverse impact on the fish in the stream.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following objectives with respect to wildlife and wildlife habitat are prescribed for the purposes of the definition of "government's environmental objectives" in section 1 (2) of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that operating areas not be located within any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a wildlife habitat area, unless an operating area will not have a material adverse effect on the ability of the wildlife habitat within the wildlife habitat area to provide for the survival, within the wildlife habitat area, of the wildlife species for which the wildlife habitat area was established;

an ungulate winter range, unless an operating area will not have a material adverse effect on the ability of the wildlife habitat within the ungulate winter range to provide for the survival, within the ungulate winter range, of the ungulate species for which the ungulate winter range was established;

a fisheries sensitive watershed, unless an operating area will not have a material adverse effect on the ability of the fisheries sensitive watershed to protect downstream fisheries and watershed values,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that oil and gas activities on an operating area outside of a wildlife habitat area be carried out at a time and in a manner that does not result in physical disturbance to high priority wildlife or their habitat, including disturbance during sensitive seasons and critical life-cycle stages,
that no portion of an operating area be within a wildlife tree retention area, and
that oil and gas activities not damage or render ineffective a wildlife habitat feature.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Old-growth management areas, resource features, cultural heritage resources
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of the definition of "government's environmental objectives" in section 1 (2) of the Act, the following objectives are prescribed:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that oil and gas activities not damage or render ineffective a resource feature;
that oil and gas activities conserve or, if necessary, protect cultural heritage resources.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In deciding whether to amend a permit under section 31 (7) of the Act or grant an extension under section 32 (5) of the Act, the commission must consider whether the amendment or extension, as applicable, is consistent with the government's environmental objectives set out in Division 1 of this Part.

This Part also applies to a holder of a master licence to cut, as defined in section 47.4 (1) of the Forest Act, as though harvesting timber under the master licence to cut is, for the purposes of sections 9 to 17 and 19 to 21 of this regulation, carrying out an oil and gas activity.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a person who is carrying out an oil and gas activity on an operating area that contains a waterworks or water supply well must ensure that the oil and gas activity does not cause a material adverse effect on the quality, quantity or flow of the water to the waterworks or water supply well.
A person is not prohibited from carrying out an oil and gas activity under subsection (1) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is not practicable to comply with subsection (1),
the adverse effect is minimized, and
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: gives notice to the owner or user of the waterworks or water supply well at least 72 hours before adversely affecting the water supply, and

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person carrying out an oil and gas activity on an operating area on top of an aquifer must ensure that the activity does not cause a material adverse effect on the quality, quantity or natural timing of flow of water in the aquifer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Crossings of streams, wetlands and lakes
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who carries out an oil and gas activity on an operating area must, for each crossing of a stream, wetland and lake, ensure all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the crossing is constructed and maintained at times and in a manner that is unlikely to harm fish or destroy, damage or harmfully alter fish habitat;
the crossing does not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prevent the movement of fish, nor
impede the movement of fish to the extent that it is harmful to the survival of the fish;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the side of the stream, wetland or lake is protected at the crossing;
any disturbance to the stream channel and stream bank, wetland, or lake bottom, as applicable, is mitigated.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: No deleterious materials into streams, wetlands or lakes
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who carries out an oil and gas activity on an operating area must ensure that the oil and gas activity does not result in any deleterious materials being deposited into a stream, wetland or lake.
A person carrying out an oil and gas activity in a wetland must, to the extent practicable, maintain natural flow of water in the wetland.

If a person carrying out an oil and gas activity on an operating area causes the removal or the rendering ineffective of a natural range barrier, the person must, before livestock is turned out on the area, or, if turnout has occurred, as soon as practicable, construct a replacement barrier that is at least as effective as the one removed or rendered ineffective was before the removal or rendering ineffective.
A person carrying out an oil and gas activity on an operating area must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make reasonable efforts to ensure that seed, plant parts or propagules of an invasive plant are not transported into the area while carrying out the oil and gas activities,

to prevent invasive plants from becoming established, revegetate areas disturbed by the oil and gas activity using seed of ecologically suitable species as soon as practicable after the disturbance, and
if on a well site or a facility area, ensure that invasive plants do not become established on the wellsite or facility area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person carrying out an oil and gas activity on an operating area that is occupied by insects harmful to forest health must not create conditions for the spread of the insects.
A person carrying out an oil and gas activity that disturbs the surface of an operating area must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not cause the soil of the area to become unstable, and
minimize any alteration to the natural surface drainage patterns on the area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person constructing a seismic line on an enclosed upland must, to the extent practicable, construct a cut line that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a maximum of 3.0 metres in width,
avoids large standing trees, and
leaves the soil and ground cover generally undisturbed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person constructing a seismic line within a riparian reserve zone must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: construct a cut line as described in subsection (1), and
to the extent practicable, retain forest cover and mature trees.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person constructing a seismic line must not damage or render ineffective a wildlife habitat feature or a resource feature.
A person who carried out an oil and gas activity on an operating area and who no longer intends to do so must, as soon as practicable, restore the operating area by doing the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: de-compacting any soils compacted by the oil and gas activity;

redistributing any retrievable surface soils that were removed from the operating area during construction so that the soil structure is restored, to the extent practicable, to its condition before the oil and gas activity was begun;
re-vegetating any exposed soil on the operating area using seed or vegetative propagules of an ecologically suitable species that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: promote the restoration of the wildlife habitat that existed on the area before the oil and gas activity was begun, and
stabilize the soil if it is highly susceptible to erosion;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: stabilizing any cut slopes or fill slopes in wellsites and facility areas;
re-contouring bladed areas or excavations in pipeline corridors and seismic lines.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 9 to 18 and 20 apply to a person restoring an operating area under subsection (1) of this section as though the person were carrying out an oil and gas activity on the operating area.
Subsection (1) (a) and (b) does not apply to an operating area that is a road right of way.

Subject to subsection (2), a person who is carrying out an oil and gas activity on an operating area must ensure that the oil and gas activity does not cause a material adverse effect on the quality, quantity or timing of flow of water to a waterworks or a water supply well located on an adjacent area.
A person is not prohibited from carrying out an oil and gas activity under subsection (1) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is not practicable to comply with subsection (1),
the adverse effect is minimized, and
the person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: gives notice to the owner or user of the waterworks or water supply well at least 72 hours before adversely affecting the water supply, and

bcl:section.bcl:text: The commission may exempt a person or a class of persons from one or more of the requirements of Divisions 1 and 2 of this Part if satisfied that, in the circumstances, it is not reasonably practicable for the person to comply with the requirement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, active flood plain means the level area with alluvial soils, adjacent to streams, that is flooded by stream water on a periodic basis and is at the same elevation as areas showing evidence of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: flood channels free of terrestrial vegetation,
rafted debris or fluvial sediments, recently deposited on the surface of the forest floor or suspended on trees or vegetation, or
recent scarring of trees by material moved by flood waters.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A stream that is a fish stream or is located in a community watershed has the following riparian class:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: S1A, if the stream averages, over a one km length, either a stream width or an active flood plain width of 100 m or greater;
S1B, if the stream width is greater than 20 m but the stream does not have a riparian class of S1A;
S2, if the stream width is not less than 5 m but not more than 20 m;
S3, if the stream width is not less than 1.5 m but is less than 5 m;
S4, if the stream width is less than 1.5 m.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A stream that is not a fish stream and is located outside of a community watershed has the following riparian class:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: S5, if the stream width is greater than 3 m;
S6, if the stream width is 3 m or less.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), for each riparian class of stream, the minimum riparian management area width, riparian reserve zone width and riparian management zone width, on each side of the stream, are as follows:
If the width of the active flood plain of a stream exceeds the specified width for the riparian management zone, the width of the riparian management zone is the outer edge of the active flood plain.
The riparian reserve zone for a stream begins at the edge of the stream channel bank and extends to the width described in subsection (4).
The riparian management zone for a stream begins at

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the outer edge of the riparian reserve zone, or
if there is no riparian reserve zone, the edge of the stream channel bank,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and extends to the width described in subsection (4).
Wetlands have the following riparian classes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: W1, if the wetland is greater than 5 ha in size but is not a wetland with a riparian class of W3;
W2, if the wetland is not less than 0.25 ha but not more than 5 ha in size;
W3, if the wetland is greater than 1000 ha in size and located in the BWBSmw1 or BWBSmw2 biogeoclimatic subzone.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For each riparian class of wetland, the minimum riparian management area width, riparian reserve zone width and riparian management zone width for the wetland are as follows:
The riparian management area for a wetland begins at the edge of the wetland and extends to the width described in subsection (2).
The size of a wetland includes any enclosed upland area encompassed by the wetland.
For greater certainty, the edge of a wetland, referred to in subsection (3), does not include the boundary between the wetland and any enclosed upland referred to in subsection (4).
Lakes have the following riparian classes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: L1-A, if the lake is 1 000 ha or greater in size;
L1-B, if the lake is greater than 5 ha but less than 1 000 ha in size;
L2, if the lake is not less than 1 ha and not more than 5 ha in size and is located in a biogeoclimatic zones or subzone that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Ponderosa Pine,
Bunch Grass,
Interior Douglas-fir, very dry hot, very dry warm or very dry mild,
Coastal Douglas-fir, or
Coastal Western Hemlock, very dry maritime, dry maritime or dry submaritime;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: L4, if the lake is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: not less than 0.25 ha and not more than 1 ha in size and is in a biogeoclimatic zone or subzone referred to in paragraph (c) (i), (ii) or (iii), or
not less than 0.5 ha and not more than 1 ha in size and is in a biogeoclimatic zone or subzone referred to in paragraph (c) (iv) or (v).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For each riparian class of lake, the minimum riparian management area width, riparian reserve zone width and riparian management zone width are as follows:
The riparian reserve zone for a lake begins at the edge of the lake and extends to the width described in subsection (2).
The riparian management zone for a lake begins at

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the outer edge of the riparian reserve zone, or
if there is no riparian reserve zone, the edge of the lake,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: and extends to the width described in subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:text: Each of the following is a resource feature:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a surface or subsurface element of a karst system;
a range development as defined under the Forest and Range Practices Act;
Crown land used for research or experimental purposes;
a trail or other recreation facility that is authorized under the Forest and Range Practices Act;
a recreation feature identified under the Forest and Range Practices Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister responsible for administering the Wildlife Act, by order, may identify any or all of the following as a wildlife habitat feature:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a fisheries sensitive feature;
a marine sensitive feature;
a significant mineral lick or wallow;
a nest of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a bald eagle,
an osprey,
a great blue heron, or
a category of species at risk that is limited to birds;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any other localized feature that the minister responsible for the Wildlife Act considers to be a wildlife habitat feature.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Identification of a wildlife habitat feature under subsection (1) may be by category or type and may be restricted to a specified geographic location.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister responsible for administering the Wildlife Act, by order, may establish a fisheries sensitive watershed in a watershed that has significant downstream fisheries values, significant fisheries values and significant watershed sensitivity if satisfied that the area requires special management to protect fish by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: conserving

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the natural hydrological conditions, natural stream bed dynamics and stream channel integrity, and
the quality, quantity and timing of water flow, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: preventing cumulative hydrological effects that would have a material adverse effect on fish.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister responsible for the Wildlife Act, by order, may identify a portion of a fish stream as a temperature sensitive stream if satisfied that trees are required adjacent to the stream to manage the temperature of the designated portion for the protection of fish.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Categories of species of wildlife established
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister responsible for administering the Wildlife Act, by order, may do any or all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: establish one or more categories identifying species of wildlife as species at risk;
establish one or more categories identifying species of wildlife as regionally important wildlife;
establish one or more categories identifying ungulate species for which an ungulate winter range may be established.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister responsible for administering the Wildlife Act, by order, may establish an area as a wildlife habitat area, if satisfied that the area is necessary to meet the habitat requirements of a category of species at risk or regionally important wildlife.

The minister responsible for administering the Wildlife Act, by order, may establish an area as an ungulate winter range, if satisfied that the area contains habitat necessary to meet the habitat requirements of a category of ungulate species.
The minister responsible for administering the Land Act by order may establish one or more areas as an old-growth management area for the purpose of providing old seral stage forest representation.
The minister responsible for administering the Land Act, by order, may establish one or more species of plants as invasive plants.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Aquifers and groundwater recharge areas identified
bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister responsible for administering the Water Sustainability Act, by order, may identify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an aquifer, and
a groundwater recharge area.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The minister responsible for administering the Water Sustainability Act, by order, may establish a watershed or a portion of a watershed, including a community watershed or a portion of a community watershed, as a designated watershed, if the minister is satisfied that the watershed or portion of the watershed requires special management to protect

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the quality or quantity of water, or
the timing of flow of water.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a minister, before making an order under sections 26, 29 or 33, must provide an opportunity for review and comment to organizations that the minister considers representative of holders of leases and licences entered into under the Petroleum and Natural Gas Act that may be affected by the order.
Subsection (1) does not apply to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under section 26 identifying a wildlife habitat feature if, before the coming into force of this section, the wildlife habitat feature was identified in an order under the Government Actions Regulation, B.C. Reg. 582/2004;

an order under section 29 establishing a species category if, before the coming into force of this section, the species category had been established as a species category by an order under the Government Actions Regulation, B.C. Reg. 582/2004;

an order under section 33 identifying a species of plant as an invasive plant if, before the coming into force of this section, the species of plant was identified as an invasive plant in Schedule A of the Weed Control Regulation, B.C. Reg. 66/85.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a minister, before making an order under any of sections 27, 28, 30 to 32, 34 or 35 must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide notice of the proposed order to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: organizations that the minister considers representative of persons who

bcl:clause.bcl:text: construct pipelines but who do not hold an associated drilling licence or lease,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that will be affected by the order, and
holders of leases or drilling licences under the Petroleum and Natural Gas Act that will be affected by the order, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: consult with persons referred to in paragraph (a) if the order may have a material adverse effect on that person.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under section 27 establishing a fisheries sensitive watershed if, before the coming into force of this section, the fisheries sensitive watershed was identified under the Government Actions Regulation, B.C. Reg. 582/2004;

an order under section 28 identifying a stream as a temperature sensitive stream if, before the coming into force of this section, the temperature sensitive stream was identified under the Government Actions Regulation, B.C. Reg. 582/2004;
an order under section 30 establishing a wildlife habitat area if, before the coming into force of this section, the wildlife habitat area was

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: continued under section 180 (b) of the Forest and Range Practices Act, or
designated under the Government Actions Regulation, B.C. Reg. 582/2004;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under section 31 establishing an ungulate winter range if, before the coming into force of this section, the ungulate winter range was

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: continued under section 180 (a) of the Forest and Range Practices Act, or
designated under the Government Actions Regulation, B.C. Reg. 582/2004;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under section 32 establishing an old-growth management area if, before the coming into force of this section, the area is spatially defined and subject to a spatial old-growth management objective that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: continued under section 93.8 of the Land Act, or
established under the Land Use Objectives Regulation, B.C. Reg. 357/2005;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under section 35 establishing a watershed or portion of a watershed as a designated watershed that is a community watershed if, before the coming into force of this section, the community watershed was

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: established under section 41 (8) to (13) of the Forest Practices Code of British Columbia Act,
continued under section 180 (e) of the Forest and Range Practices Act, or
designated under the Government Actions Regulation, B.C. Reg. 582/2004.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An order made under section 26 to 35

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: comes into force on the date that notice of the order is published in the Gazette, and
does not apply to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: oil and gas activities permitted by a permit issued before the order comes into force, or
an application for a permit under section 25, 31 or 32 of the Act if the application was submitted to the commission before the order comes into force.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each of the ministers responsible for administering the Wildlife Act, the Water Sustainability Act and the Land Act, respectively, may, in writing, do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: delegate a power or duty of that minister under Division 2 to one or more of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: another minister;
a person or class of persons employed under the Public Service Act;
an official;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vary or revoke a delegation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A delegation under subsection (1) may be made generally or in relation to one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: particular circumstances;
particular periods;
particular geographic areas;
particular persons or classes of persons.
